s.text: Persistent microalbuminuria should be confirmed on two or three subsequent readings within a six-month period to rule out false-positive results.

A 31-year-old white male with no significant past medical history is referred by his workplace to a primary care physician for an elevated blood pressure (BP).
The ADA recommends glycemic and other CVD risk factor goals (see Table 2), in addition to foot evaluation and screening for nephropathy and retinopathy, for all adults with diabetes [4].
The remainder of his examination is unchanged, including normal fundoscopy.
His creatinine and liver enzymes are normal.
His creatinine and liver enzymes are normal.
His additional investigations are as follows: fasting glucose, 215 mg/dl; hemoglobin A1c (HbA 1c ), 8.6%; and urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio, 2.0 mg/mmol (normal is <2.
His creatinine and liver enzymes are normal.
His creatinine and liver enzymes are normal.
He has nocturia and has lost 5 lb in the last week.
It may be timely to address the prevention of diabetes in patients with metabolic syndrome since these patients are at high risk for development of type 2 diabetes.
It is important to continue emphasis on dietary, exercise, and lifestyle modifications in addition to pharmacotherapy.
It is important to continue emphasis on dietary, exercise, and lifestyle modifications in addition to pharmacotherapy.
The patient is started on an exercise and weight loss program, sent for nutritional counseling, and scheduled for a return clinic appointment for three months later.
Intensive lifestyle modifications such as exercise and weight loss should be made to improve cholesterol, blood pressure, and other cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors [2].

In addition, continued strict BP control is as effective as tight glycemic control in preventing macrovasular disease in diabetic patients and slowing the progression of diabetic nephropathy and retinopathy [12].

Intensive therapy in patients with type 2 diabetes results in a decreased risk of microvascular complications; therefore, it is appropriate to use combinations of medications in patients with suboptimal glycemia [21].

Insulin and insulin-sensitizer combinations significantly improve hyperglycemia; however, there is an increased incidence of heart failure reported with this combination, prompting close monitoring of patients for signs and symptoms of heart failure [27].

Insulin and insulin-sensitizer combinations significantly improve hyperglycemia; however, there is an increased incidence of heart failure reported with this combination, prompting close monitoring of patients for signs and symptoms of heart failure [27].
Insulin is used in a variety of combinations and is individualized to patient lifestyle.

Insulin and insulin-sensitizer combinations significantly improve hyperglycemia; however, there is an increased incidence of heart failure reported with this combination, prompting close monitoring of patients for signs and symptoms of heart failure [27].
Therapy with metformin appears to decrease the risk of diabetes-related endpoints, including a reduction in cardiovascular events independent of glycemic control.
